coredata.dc:title: Carbon K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structures of solid C70
coredata.dc:creator: Shinohara, Hisanori
Sato, Hiroyasu
Saito, Yahachi
Tohji, Kazuyuki
Matsuoka, Isao
Udagawa, Yasuo
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The carbon K-edge absorption spectra of microcyrstalline C70 have been measured using 270–330 eV synchrotron radiation and compared with that of a previously reported microcrystalline C60. The differences in the cage structure between the C70 and C60 fullerenes are clearly reflected in their XANES (X-ray absorption near-edge structures) features. The C70 cluster contains a significant fraction of sp2 hybridized carbon bonds as revealed by the presence of a prominent π* resonance in the XANES spectrum.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 183, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 23 August 1991 Carbon K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structures of solid C70 Hisanori Shinohara a.l Hiroyasu Sato ~, Yahachi Saito b, Kazuyuki Tohji lsao Matsuoka C and Yasuo Udagawa6l Department of Chemistry for Materials, Mi e University, Tsu 514, Japan Department of Elect rica! Engineering, M: e University, T.su 514. Japan. C Department of Resources Engineering, Tohoku University, Sendai 980, Japan Research Inst it ute for Scientific Measurements, Tohoku University, Sendai 980, Japan Received 3 May 1991; in finalform 7iune 1991 The carbon K-edge absorption spectra of microcrystalline C70 have been measured using 270 330 eV Synchrotron radiation and compared with that of a previously reported microcrystalline Cm. The differences in the cage structure between the C70 and C~ fullerenes are clearly reflected in their XANES (X-ray absorption near-edge structures) features. The C70 cluster contains a significant fraction of sp2 hybridized carbon bonds as revealed by the presence of a prominent ii resonance in the XANES spectrum. 1. Introduction Since the recent success of macroscopic prepara- tion of C60 (buckminsterfullerene) [1,2], C70 [3,4], and C84 [4,5], a number of spectroscopic studies have been performed on these novel forms of carbon clusters. The isolation of these fullerenes was real- ized because they cannot accrete more carbon atoms and are spectacularly resistant to further growth un- der various experimental conditions [6]. The trun- cated icosahedral soccerball structure of C60, pro- posed by Smalley and co-workers [7] in 1985, is now established on the basis of 3C NMR studies of C60 [3,4,8]. Also the results of the 3C NMR studies of C70 in various solvents are consistent with the pic- ture that C70 has a rugbyball-like cage structure with an increased number of hexagonal rings [4,6]. The breakthrough has confirmed the potential im- portance of the fullerenes in diverse areas from syn- thetic chemistry [9], through solid-state physics [10], to astronomy [11]. Recently, we have reported a carbon K-edge XANES (X-ray absorption near-edge structures) study of microcrystalline C60 [12]. In general XANES features are sensitive to the local symmetry To whom correspondence should be addressed. and the type of chemical bonding of the exciting atom and can be useful as fingerprints to distinguish struc- tures [13,14]. As expected, the carbon K-shell XANES features of the microcrystalline C~ were quite different from those of graphite and diamond [12]. The characteristic features observed in the ir~ band in the C60 spectrum were attributed to a cage- strained it-bond network constrained in the cage structure [12]. Furthermore, the observed band structures were in good agreement with a theoretical prediction recently reported by Saito and Osbiyama [15]. In this Letter, we report a carbon K-shell XANES study of microcrystalline C70 fullerene, which uti- lizes 270 330 eV synchrotron radiation. According to the previous 3C NMR studies [3,4,8], C70 has a Dsh rugyball-like structure in contrast with an h soccerball structure of C60 [7]. The observed 7L and a~ absorption features are quite different from those of C60. The differences in the cage structure be- tween the C70 and C60 fullerenes are clearly reflected in the observed XANES spectra. 2. Experimental The experimental details have been described in a 0009-2614/9l/$ 03.50 1991 E1s~vier Science Publishers B.V, All rights reserved. 145 ~~~___ (a) (b) Volume 183, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETFERS 23 August 1991 previous publication [12]. The X-ray absorption ex- periments have been performed on the BL-2Bl Beam Line of UVSOR (ultra-violet synchrotron radia- tion) at the Institute for Molecular Science. The ra- diation is monochromatized with a grasshopper monochromator (600 lines/mm, a mechanically ruled grating). The energy resolution of the mono- chromator with the grating is 0.8 eV at around the carbon K-edge. The photoabsorption spectra of solid C70 are taken by recording the total electron yield from the sample as a function of photon energy [16]. A collimated X- ray beam impinges on an Au-coated tungsten-mesh grid of high transmission (70%). The leak current from this grid, amplified by ,an electrometer (Keith- ley model 617), serves as a dynamic intensity mon- itor [16]. The X-ray beam is then incident on the sample under investigation. The detection is per- formed at 90 relative to the incident X-ray beam. The electron-yield signal is detected by a ceratron electron multiplier (Murata EME-206 1B). Typical output currents of the electron multiplier in our measurements are of the order of i0~ i 0~ A. Background structures exist at the K-absorption edge of carbon, which are due to carbon contami- nants deposited on the optical surfaces. A normali- zation subtraction procedure to eliminate the back- ground structures has already been described previously [12]. Absolute energy calibration is made by use of two transmission minima at 284.7 and 291.0 eV, which come from the carbon contamina- tiOn [17]. The C60 and C70 samples have been prepared fol- lowing the method described by Kratschmer et a!. (1]. A graphite rod is evaporated by resistive heat- ing under partial helium pressure of 100 200 Torr. The carbon sootlike deposit is scraped from the in- side of the vacuum chamber. Soluble products are extracted from the deposit by the Soxhlet method with boiling benzene. Extraction is judged to be complete (8 h) when dark red-brown material ceases to leach from the Soxhiet thimble. The so-obtained liquid is known to contain C70 and other fullerenes in addition to C60 [3,4,8,9]. The concentrated ex- tract is subjected to column chromatography using neutral alumina (ICN BIOMEDICALS Akt. I) with hexanes as eluent [12]. Elution with haxanes then produces two colored bands: the first (purple-ma- genta) consisting of pure (99%) C60, and the second (dark-orange) consisting of C70 (>95%). The sam- ple purity is checked by high-pressure liquid chro- matography. Samples of C70 microcrystallites are prepared by dropping the chromatographed C70 so- lution on the Au-plate. Evaporations of the eluent are performed at 250 C. 3. Results and discussion The carbon K-edge photoabsorption spectrum of microcrystalline C70 at room temperature is dis- played in fig. la. Several band peaks and shoulders are clearly seen. The three bands appearing at 284.8, 287.4, and 291.2 eV are particularly salient. The res- onance labeled it~ corresponds to a transition of a~ antibonding orbitals (or, more precisely, x~ bands in the case of the solids) [12,141. Between 290 and 310 eV, transitions to antibonding orbitals are observed. The XANES spectrum of C70 resembles that of graphite [12,14] irs terms of the presence ofals~_#n* transition appearing at 284.8 eV, though the overall spectral features are entirely different (vide infra). The transition energies and proposed assignments of C70, along with those of C60 [12], are listed in table I I 280 290 300 310 320 E~ERGY/ eV Fig. 1. Carbon K-shell XANES spectra of solid (a) C70 and (b) Cm. The resonance labeled z corresponds to transitions to the antibonding orbital. Between 290 and 307 eV, transitions to n antibonding orbitals are observed. The intensities of the two spectra are normalized at 325.8 eV, so that a direct comparison of the absorption intensity is possible. 146 C70 E(eV) C00 E(eV) io resonance 284.8 284.5 (sh.) 287.4 285.5 287.4 ,rresonance (288,8) 291.2 291.7 293.2 294.0 294.5 296. I o resonance 297.5 297.5 300.0 299.5 304.4 Taken from ref. [12]. Volume 183, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 23 August 1991 Table I Transition energies, E (cv), and proposed assignment in the car- bon K-shell XANES spectra of C70 and C~ ~ cause of large intercluster overlaps of the it bond which spreads outside the clusters [15]. As seen in the C70 spectrum, two it~ peaks at 284.8 and 287.4 eV (and possibly one shoulder at 288.8 eV) and seven cy 0 peaks and shoulders in the region of 291.2 304.4 eV are observed. It can also be seen from figs. I a and lb) that the absorption intensity of both the it 0 and a~ transitions is larger in C70 than in C60. Furthermore, the relative intensity and the band width of the it~ transition (with respect to the a 0 transition) are increased on going from C60 (5.6 eV, fwhm) to C70 (6.3 eV). These results are indic- ative of the fact that in the C70 solid, the level density of both the jr~ and the o~ transitions are increased in reference to C60 and that those of the sc resonance are particularly increased. A very recent density-of- state (DOS) calculation of C70 by Saito [19] using the local-density approximation in the density-func- tional theory also indicates that the DOS of the it 0 state of C70 is larger than that of Cso. Furthermore, most of the spectral positions of the observed peaks and shoulders (both it and a~ states) are in good agreement with the DOS calculation. The C70 cluster is generated formally by separating two halves of C60 by a ring of ten extra carbon atoms to form a rugbyball, where twelve pentagonal and twentyfive hexagonal rings sit on the cluster cage. The structure is consistent with the recent 3C NMR studies of C70 in various solvents [3,4,8]. A part of the C70 surface thus becomes a smoothly curving net with more-or-less flat ellipsoidal surface. For ex- ample, there exist curved tetracene- and perene- like n-bond networks of hexagonal rings on the C70 surface, which are not existent on the C60 cage. In this context, C70 is much more graphite-like than C60. The increasing graphite-like character in C70 is consistent with the XANES observation that the level density of the it~ transition of C70 is particularly increased. In C70, there are at least two types of it0 electronic configurations interacting with each other: one cor- responding to a state of graphite (graphite-like it- electron network) and the other to a less delocalized it state which is characteristic of a cage-strained it- bond network of C70 [12,20,21]. One of the prob- able cage-strained it-bond networks consists of a pentagonal ring surrounded by five hexagonal rings. A very recent measurement on the magnetic suscep The presence of the it~ resonance at 284.8 eV is characteristic of unsaturated (sp2 or sp) carbon bonds [14,16,18]. Its prominent intensity in the C70 cluster, therefore, indicates the presence of unsatu- rated C C bonds as in graphite and amorphous car- bon (but in contrast to diamond) [14]. However, another prominent it~ peak is observed at 287.4 eV in the C70 spectrum. This is in marked contrast to the XANES spectra of the other forms of solid car- bon [14]. A similar fine structure has been observed so far only in the C60 spectrum as reported previ- ously [12]. In order to examine the angular depen- dence of the XANES features, the microcrystalline samples are rotated 20 ~80 relative to the incident X-ray beam. No spectral changes are observed. This guarantees that the present absorption spectrum re- flects the density-of-states of the unoccupied states of C70. For comparison, the XANES spectrum of micro- crystalline C60 is reproduced in fig. lb. The C60 spec- trum exhibits peaks at 285.5 (lr*), 287.4 (it 0), 291.7 (o 0) 294.5 (a ), 297.5 (o~), and 299.5 (r 0) eV, most of which agree well with the recent theoretical studies of Saito and Oshiyama [15,19] on the band structure of the fcc C60 solid. In the light of their cal- culation, for example, the origin of the it~ band peaks at 285.5 and 287.4 eV can be assigned as the g~ .t20 and g5-/h~ transitions, respectively. They found that most levels between 6 and + 7 eV (HOMO = 0 eV) had considerable dispersions in the fcc crystal be- 147 Volume 183, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LE1TERS 23 August 1991 tibility of C60 and C70 [22] indicates that the mag- netic susceptibility of C70 is found to be twice that of C60, indicating the presence of an increased graph- ite-like character of the it-bond network in C70. In general, as the number of five-membered rings is fixed at twelve in these fullerenes, with a higher frac- tion of six-membered rings the larger fullerenes should show much enhanced it-electron delocaliza- tion, ultimately approaching the averaged value for graphite. The results of the present study are also consistent with this tendency. The polarization XANES measurements of oriented crystals (or films) of both C60 and C70 will be needed for a further elu- cidation of their band structures. Acknowledgement We wish to thank Dr. S. Saito for sharing his cal- culations with us prior to publication. This research was supported in part by the Okasan-Kato Science and Technology Foundation. References [11W. Kratschmer, L.D. Lamb, K. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The carbon K-edge absorption spectra of microcyrstalline C70 have been measured using 270–330 eV synchrotron radiation and compared with that of a previously reported microcrystalline C60. The differences in the cage structure between the C70 and C60 fullerenes are clearly reflected in their XANES (X-ray absorption near-edge structures) features. The C70 cluster contains a significant fraction of sp2 hybridized carbon bonds as revealed by the presence of a prominent π* resonance in the XANES spectrum.
